channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: United States Criticizes Israel Over West Bank Settlement Plan
item.media:description: The Obama administration has condemned the Israeli government for approving plans to create a new Jewish settlement on the West Bank. The Eli settlement (foreground), pictured in 2015, overlooks Palestinian villages in the West Bank.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: The Obama administration said the move violated the pledge by Israel not to construct new Jewish settlements and ran counter to its long-term security interests.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Israel Halts Yacht Trying to Break Its Blockade of Gaza Strip
item.media:description: Palestinians gathered on Wednesday at a seaport in Gaza City to welcome the Zaytouna-Oliva, a yacht with an all-female crew that had tried to break Israel’s blockade of the Gaza Strip.
item.description: The all-female crew of the Zaytouna-Oliva had hoped to reach the Palestinian enclave, but knew ahead of time the mission’s chances of success were slim.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and MAJD AL WAHEIDI

item.title: Europe Makes Deal to Send Afghans Home, Where War Awaits Them
item.media:description: Afghan migrants at a temporary camp on the Greek island of Lesbos last year. Under a new deal, tens of thousands of migrants, whose asylum applications were rejected in Europe, will be forced to leave.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Tens of thousands of Afghans could be deported in the deal, just as the Taliban war has intensified, killing and wounding more civilians than ever.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Call Centers in India Posed as I.R.S. to Cheat U.S. Taxpayers, Authorities Say
item.description: More than 600 people were under investigation for posing as I.R.S. officers and sending text messages to American cellphone numbers demanding money.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Marshall Islands Can’t Sue the World’s Nuclear Powers, U.N. Court Rules
item.media:description: Phon van den Biesen, center left, the Dutch lawyer who led the Marshall Islands team, at the court session in The Hague on Wednesday.
item.description: The International Court of Justice said it did not have jurisdiction because there was no evidence of a legal dispute that it could adjudicate.
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Security Council Backs António Guterres to Be Next U.N. Secretary General
item.media:description: António Guterres, then the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, in 2014. Mr. Guterres won a straw poll to become the next secretary general.
item.description: The Security Council announced that Mr. Guterres, a former Portuguese prime minister and former chief of the United Nations refugee agency, had strong support.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Hurricane Matthew: Photos of the Destruction in Haiti
item.media:description: Streets in the city of Les Cayes, on Haiti’s southwestern coast, were underwater as a result of Hurricane Matthew.
item.description: The storm killed at least 25 on its path through the island of Hispaniola, according to Reuters. But the authorities are just beginning efforts to fully assess the damage.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Winnipeg Journal: A Museum About Rights, and a Legacy of Uncomfortable Canadian Truths
item.media:description: The Canadian Museum for Human Rights in Winnipeg has become a symbol of the contradictions between the nation’s modern multicultural identity and what critics say is an unreconciled legacy of human rights violations against indigenous peoples that continue to this day.
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.description: Backers of the Canadian Museum for Human Rights say it starts important conversations about injustice, but some aboriginal people say it plays down their continuing plight.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: 2 Brussels Police Officers Are Stabbed in ‘Potential Terrorist Attack’
item.media:description: Police officers at the scene of the stabbing in the Schaerbeek neighborhood of Brussels on Wednesday.
item.description: A man attacked two officers in the Schaerbeek district on Wednesday, not long after bomb scares led to the evacuations of a train station and a government building.
item.dc:creator: MILAN SCHREUER and ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Theresa May, British Premier, Urges Conservatives to Claim ‘New Center Ground’
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain spoke at the Conservative Party’s annual conference on Wednesday.
item.description: Mrs. May, speaking at her party’s convention, sought to court disaffected working-class voters and vowed to rein in abuses by big business.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Stepping Over the Dead on a Migrant Boat
item.description: What a photographer saw when a rescue vessel went into action off the Libyan coast.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Sinosphere: Recognizing Boarding Schools’ Psychic Toll in China
item.media:description: A boy balances on bed frames while others play card games in the dormitory of their boarding school in Hunan Province, China. Boarding children under the age of six is less common now than before, but remains a respectable option.
item.description: Stoic and emotional reactions at a seminar in Beijing hinted at the fallout from the widespread practice of sending young children to live away from home.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Trilobites: On Epic Spawning Migration, Eels May Travel at Their Own Pace
item.media:description: A European eel in the Baltic Sea.
item.media:credit: Reinhard Dirscherl/Ullstein bild via Getty Images
item.description: For a century, scientists have assumed that European eels synchronize their journeys to breed in the Sargasso Sea. A new study suggests otherwise.
item.dc:creator: STEPH YIN

item.title: Panti Bliss, Ireland’s Queen of Drag, Expands Her Kingdom
item.media:description: Panti Bliss, the alter ego of Rory O’Neill, prepares her hair in New York in 2015.
item.media:credit: Mark Kauzlarich for The New York Times
item.description: “It’s pretty wild how queer Ireland has become,” says her alter ego, Rory O’Neill, an activist who played a big role in legalizing same-sex marriage.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Sinosphere: Half of Chinese Favorable Toward U.S., but Many See a Threat, a Survey Finds
item.media:description: Chinese watching the first United States presidential debate at a cafe in Beijing last week. Half of Chinese surveyed by the Pew Research Center had a favorable view of the United States, up from 44 percent last year.
item.description: Most Chinese want their government to focus on domestic issues rather than on helping other nations, the survey also found.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Bangladesh Siege Recalled in Militant’s Words, and From Beyond the Grave
item.media:description: A police checkpoint near the site of a bloody siege in Dhaka, Bangladesh, in July.
item.description: An article in an Islamic State publication bears the byline of Tamim Ahmed Chowdhury, a militant who was killed with two associates in a police raid in late August.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and MAHER SATTAR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: 3 Makers of World’s Smallest Machines Awarded Nobel Prize in Chemistry
item.media:description: Bernard L. Feringa, a professor of organic chemistry at the University of Groningen, in the Netherlands, was one of the three winners of the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, announced Wednesday, who were cited for their work in developing molecule-size machines.
item.media:credit: Jeroen Van Kooten/University of Groningen, via Associated Press
item.description: Jean-Pierre Sauvage, J. Fraser Stoddart and Bernard L. Feringa won for their work on “molecular machines” that can be used to develop new materials, sensors and energy storage systems.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Myanmar Repeals 1950 Law Long Used to Silence Dissidents
item.media:description: President Htin Kyaw of Myanmar and the leader of the National League for Democracy, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, in March. Parliament voted this week to put an end to the Emergency Provisions Act.
item.description: Among other measures, the law had authorized prison terms of up to seven years for reading foreign newspapers or listening to broadcasters like the BBC.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sinosphere: As China Strikes Deals, U.S. Considers Expanding Foreign Reviews
item.media:description: Spectators waiting for a film to start at the AMC Loews Kips Bay theater in Manhattan. The Dalian Wanda Group, a Chinese conglomerate, bought AMC Theaters in 2012 for $2.6 billion.
item.description: A government auditing agency will study whether American officials should broaden how they inspect foreign purchases in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)

item.title: What in the World: In Senegal, Absolution Comes With a Wing and a Prayer
item.description: In Dakar and other cities, men stand on street corners with cages of red-billed firefinches, which people buy and release to get rid of sins and anxiety.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: What in the World: Need to Land a Plane? In Australia, They Break Out the Toilet Paper
item.description: For the Royal Flying Doctor Service to arrive and land on a remote runway at night, about 30 cans with flaming rolls sometimes have to be lined up.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Royal Flying Doctor Service of Australia

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Don’t Intervene in Syria
item.description: With the cease-fire collapsed and horrific violence in Aleppo, American intervention might seem tempting. It’s still a bad idea.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN SIMON and JONATHAN STEVENSON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Editorial: A New Voice for a Complicated World
item.description: António Guterres of Portugal should make an effective United Nations secretary general, when his nomination is approved by the General Assembly.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Editorial: President Duterte, the Wild Card in U.S.-Filipino Relations
item.media:description: Police block protesters trying to get near the U.S. embassy in Manila during a rally against the Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement on Tuesday.
item.description: In his three months in office, President Rodrigo Duterte has found many ways to damage his country’s ties to America.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
